body: The filesystem doesn't allow setting the modification time of files, for some reason. Syncthing can't work in that environment.
So Syncthing all of a sudden can't work on Android anymore? Because after #818 is fixed I get "puller: final: chtimes [path]: operation not permitted". The Ignore permissions checkbox is set.

issue.title: Sync stopped working with 0.5.1
issue.body:
After updating to 0.5.1 and all non-Android nodes to syncthing 0.10.0, sync between the Android versions and the other devices stopped working, items remain out of sync on the Android devices. In the Web GUI, I see the following error messages ([syncedFolder] being the exact path of one repository, [filename.ext] being one filename in the synced folder):

15:34:10: puller: final: chmod /storage/emulated/0/[syncedFolder]/.syncthing.[filename.ext]: operation not permitted
15:34:10: puller: final: chmod /storage/emulated/0/[syncedFolder]/.syncthing.[filename.ext]: operation not permitted
15:34:10: puller: final: chmod /storage/emulated/0/[syncedFolder]/.syncthing.[filename.ext]: operation not permitted
15:34:10: Folder "passwords" isn't making progress - check logs for possible root cause. Pausing puller for 1m0s.
15:34:10: Folder "mobile" isn't making progress - check logs for possible root cause. Pausing puller for 1m0s.

body:
Also seeing this on Android with 0.10.1 . Let me know if you need logs.

Scott
I'm still seeing this on nutomic's syncthing-android 0.5.2 (syncthing 0.10.1), as well.
+1 on this. 0.5.2 not syncing with the chtimes error.

Can I see an `ls -l` of a file and/or the containing directory that fails this way? I rather suspect the bug might have been the other way, i.e. it didn't work previously either but wasn't reported properly...

Last time this came up, these links were circulated:

https://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=169913
https://code.google.com/p/android/issues/detail?id=199210

They basically say that changing modification times on files doesn't work on Android. Syncthing needs that to work. :/

![screenshot_2014-10-13-14-34-46](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2217075/4613424/93855bf0-52d5-11e4-85bd-ac92f13addf5.png)
this is a screenshot of ls -la on the folder. it is the "Music" folder.. subfolders are getting synced how ever there are not any files synced
:( does that mean it won't work ever?

@beyondthewall Thanks! I won't say "ever", but the current mechanism for syncing requires that we be able to set the modification time to the expected value, or we can't detect if the file has changed afterwards. There are workarounds that could be made around this though. Out of curiosity, what happens here with 0.9.19 for example?
i use the fdroid version(0.5.2) which comes with 0.10.1 so can't say.. did the detecting mechanism change since then?
@calmh, so the old puller used best attempt to Chtime, new puller insists on it.

Right, yeah. So with the old behaviour, we'd sync the contents, fail to set the mtime, detect it as changed on next scan, and sync the changed time back to the other devices. With the new behaviour we fail to sync instead. Which is better, but of course annoying if the old, buggy, behavior was OK.

If we actually want to work around this, we should probably keep an index of mtime-as-seen-on-disk to actual-mtime-in-index to "emulate" the lack working mtimes...

So the best we can do is to downgrade Syncthing-android to the version with the old puller and wait patiently for the workaround, as it seems to me that it won't be fast. If I remember correctly on protocol level they are compatible? Am I right?

issue.title: Syncthing-android updates file modification times on initial sync
issue.body:
I am having an issue where Syncthing-android resets file modificaiton times to the time of initial sync on the Android device. These modification times are propagated through the cluster. I consider this a data loss.

My cluster consists of four machines:
android 0.4.3 syncthing v0.8.20 (this project)
darwin-amd64-v0.8.21
linux-armv7-v0.8.21
linux-amd64-v.0.8.21

Here is how I reproduce this bug.

I stop syncthing on every machine in the cluster. I `rm ./*` from within the repo directory on each machine. Now the repo exists but is completely empty. Then, I `rsync -a` my files into the repo of one machine (specifically, the darwin v0.8.21) from a backup. These files have diverse modification times.

When I start the cluster without the android machine, the files sync normally, propagating the correct modification times to each machine in the cluster.

When I add the android machine with an empty repo, it syncs the files from the cluster to itself, but it erroneously updates the modification time of the received files to the present time. These updated modification times are then propagated to the rest of the cluster.

Modification times are important information to me and I don't think it's normal behavior to update them when syncing.

Please let me know if I can provide any logs or debug traces to assist you.

body: Changed the issue description. It would be nice if syncing could run without syncing mtime, similar to how we can run without syncing permissions. It requires being a bit more smart about detecting changes, though; either by having a persistent lookup table of actual mtime => virtual mtime, or by doing something like a full expensive rescan on startup and caching the mtimes in RAM (less desirable all around I think).

@Nutomic With the above commit in place, you can add a `<lenientMtimes>true</lenientMtimes>` to the folder configuration to restore the old v0.9 behaviour. Note that two Android devices running with that setting will never get in sync though.
Will do, thanks for the quick workaround :)
